The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of kepone with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 0.0 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(3) indicating it is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). However, kepone readily forms hydrates on exposure to ordinary temperatures and humidities(4). Vapor-phase kepone hydrate is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 38 days(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 2.8X10-13 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(3). Particulate-phase kepone may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). Kepone and kepone hydrate are susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(5,6).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: An experiment using activated sludge found that <0.1% of the applied kepone was metabolised after three days(1). A similar study employed a freshwater laboratory microcosm and the results showed a half-life in estuarine sediments for kepone to be >312 days(2). In a study conducted on James River sediments with added autoclaved silty loam soil, kepone showed no degradation after 52 days at pH=7(3). Hydrosoils from a reservoir with no prior exposure to kepone and that were subsequently exposed to kepone and hydrosoils from a kepone-contaminated creek both showed no biodegradation under aerobic conditions after 56 days(4). The amount of kepone recovered from sea water under aerobic conditions for 1 year was 95%(5).

Reference: (1) Fernandez-Bayo JD et al; Sci Total Environ 463-464: 395-403 (2013)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: The mineralization of 14C-kepone was investigated in microcosm studies using two tropical andosol soils over a total incubation period of 215 days(1). The 14-CO2 evolution reached 4.9% and 3.2% in the two soils. Much lower 14-CO2 evolution occurred in sterilized soil microcosms indicating a microbial origin of the degradation. The rate of mineralized decreased throughout the incubation period(1).

Reference: (1) Orndorff SA, Colwell RR; Appl Environ Microbiol 39: 398-406 (1980) as cited in WHO; Environ Health Criteria 43: Chlordecone. World Health Org, Geneve, Switzerland (1984). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://www.inchem.org/pages/ehc.html

StringWithMarkup.String: Microbial action has been shown to transform kepone into monohydro- and dihydro-kepone(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Chlordecone (C10Cl10O; CAS number 143-50-0) has been used extensively as an organochlorine insecticide but is nowadays banned and listed on annex A in The Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs). Although experimental evidences of biodegradation of this compound are scarce, several dechlorination products have been proposed by Dolfing et al. (2012) using Gibbs free energy calculations to explore different potential transformation routes. We here present the results of an in silico classification (TyPol - Typology of Pollutants) of chlordecone transformation products (TPs) based on statistical analyses combining several environmental endpoints and structural molecular descriptors. Starting from the list of putative chlordecone TPs and considering available data on degradation routes of other organochlorine compounds, we used different clustering strategies to explore the potential environmental behaviour of putative chlordecone TPs from the knowledge on their molecular descriptors. The method offers the possibility to focus on TPs present in different classes and to infer their environmental fate. Thus, we have deduced some hypothetical trends for the environmental behaviour of TPs of chlordecone assuming that TPs, which were clustered away from chlordecone, would have different environmental fate and ecotoxicological impact compared to chlordecone. Our findings suggest that mono- and di-hydrochlordecone, which are TPs of chlordecone often found in contaminated soils, may have similar environmental behaviour in terms of persistence.

Reference: (1) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Mirex and Chlordecone. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (1995). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp

(3) Huckins JN et al; J Agric food Chem 30: 1020-1027 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: ANAEROBIC: Anaerobic biodegradation is a degradation process for kepone in soil or sediments, however, it is a very slow removal process(1). The amount of kepone recovered from sea water under anaerobic conditions for 1 year was 95%(2). Hydrosoils from a reservoir with no prior exposure to kepone and that were subsequently exposed to kepone and hydrosoils from a kepone-contaminated creek both showed no biodegradation under anaerobic conditions after 56 days(3).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of kepone with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 0.0 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1) indicating it is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). Kepone readily forms hydrates on exposure to ordinary temperatures and humidities(2) and, in solution, kepone can exist in the carbonyl form and as its hydrate, a gem-diol(3). The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of kepone hydrate with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 2.8X10-13 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1); this corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 38 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). The direct photolysis of kepone may be possible in the environmental UV spectrum(4). A study found that photolysis of kepone in the presence of oxygen resulted in the formation of carbon dioxide and hydrogen chloride; however, no specific information concerning rates or amounts were provided(4). Irradiation of kepone dihydrate yielded the same photolysis products as irradiation of Mirex(5). The photolysis degradation products of kepone hydrate in solution were found to be monohydrokepone and dihydrokepone(3).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

(2) Spehar RL; J Water Pollut Control Fed 54: 877-922 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: Mean BCF values ranging from 900-9,354 were measured for kepone using sheepshead minnows (Cyprinodon variegatus), spot fish (Leiostomus xanthurus), and oysters (Crassostrea virginica) during 4 to 28 day exposure flow-through tests(1). BCF values of 1,100-2,200 were reported for fathead minnow (Pimephales promelas)(2) and a BCF of 8,400 was reported for fish (unnamed species)(3). According to a classification scheme(2), these BCF values suggest the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high(SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC). Based on measured uptake and clearances rates, equilibrium BCFs were estimated for Brevoortia tyrannus (Atlantic menhaden), 2,300-9,750, and Menidia menidia (Atlantic silversides), 217,00-602,00(5).

Reference: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 1372

StringWithMarkup.String: Chlorococcum species (algae) exposed to 100 ug/L/24 hr exhibited a bioconcentration factor of 800X. Dunaliella tertiolecta (algae) exposed to 100 ug/L/24 hr exhibited a bioconcentration factor of 230X. Nitzschia species (algae) exposed to 100 ug/L/24 hr exhibited a bioconcentration factor of 410X. Thalassisiva pseudonana (algae) exposed to 100 ug/L/24 hr exhibited a bioconcentration factor of 520X. Spartina cynosuroides (giant cordgrass) detritus absorbs kepone from contaminated brackish waters during decomposition. Concentrations of kepone on detritus increased from 0.5 ug/g dry weight after 14 days of decomposition to 4.5 ug/g dry weight after 119 days.

StringWithMarkup.String: An aquatic laboratory model ecosystem was deployed in an evaluation of the insecticide kepone. Kepone was degraded to some extent during the 33-day study period. In addition, kepone was biomagnified by the algal, snail, fish, and mosquito species. Kepone was the least bioaccumulative, as compared to Mirex and photomirex(1).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Fernandez-Bayo JD et al; Sci Total Environ 463-464: 395-403 (2013)
(2) Schuurmann G et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 7005-7011 (2006); Supporting information. Available from, as of Oct 12, 2016: https://pubs.acs.org/doi/suppl/10.1021/es060152f

(4) Sanborn JR et al; The Degradation of Selected Pesticides in Soil: A Review of the Published Literature NTIS PB 272 353 (1977)

StringWithMarkup.String: In a microcosm study using two andosol tropical soils, measured soil Kd values of 320 and 70(1) correspond to respective Koc values of 7440 and 3330(SRC). Kepone also has a reported experimental log Koc value of 4.20 (Koc of 15850)(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these Koc values suggest that kepone is expected to be immobile in soil. In laboratory leaching studies, the percent of kepone that leached through soil cylinders 80 cm deep were as follows: clay loam, 1.2%; clay, 17.2%; sandy clay loam, 36.8%; sandy loam, 28.1%(4).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

(2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for kepone is estimated as 5.4X10-8 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) derived from its vapor pressure, 2.25X10-7 mm Hg(1), and water solubility, 2.7 mg/L(1). The Henry's Law constant indicates that kepone is expected to be essentially nonvolatile from water surfaces(2). Kepone's estimated Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil is not expected to occur(SRC). Kepone is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon its vapor pressure(1). However, laboratory tests have measured small amounts of kepone volatilization from soil and water(1). Volatilization was slower from water than from sand, loam or humus soil(1). Percent kepone volatilized per mL evaporated water at 25 °C from 50 mL water, first hr, 0.025%; second hr, 0.024%; percent volatilized from soil, 1st hr (2nd hr), sandy soil, 0.029 (0.036); loamy soil, 0.038 (0.035); humus soil, 0.029 (0.032)(1). It was estimated that up to 16% of applied kepone may volatilize from loamy soil outdoors over a time-span of 1 vegetation period(1).

Kepone was used in banana plantations of the French West Indies to control the weevil, Cosmopolites sordidus(2); despite its prohibition in France in 1993, pollution surveys conducted in 2001 in the French West Indies by the French Department of Health revealed the presence of chlordecone in soils, rivers, springs and drinking water(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: In 1976 during dredging operations in the James River, seven stations examined water samples with 61-71% of the samples testing positive for kepone, depending on the time and depth of sampling(1). Results were as follows: surface, 1 sample, 77 parts per trillion, 1.5-6 m depth, 8 samples, 63% positive, 46-579 parts per trillion, average of positive, 500 parts per trillion; centrifuged and filtered sediment supernatent, 902 ppm, surface water, 897 ppm(1). The Chesapeake Bay contained 0.04-0.08 ppm of kepone in 1976(2). A similar study found Lake Ontario and Lake St. Clair to contain undetermined amounts of kepone, while no kepone was detected in Lake Erie(3). Kepone was not detected in water samples collected from six sites around Hong Kong in 2002 and 2003 (detection limit not reported)(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: A detailed study of the James River (Virginia) found that kepone contaminated the bed sediments along a major portion of the river bed, due to the adsorption of kepone to fine particles and organic matter(1): Jan-March, 1976, 49-870 ppb kepone(1); April, 1976, 2070 ppb, July, 15 (during dredging operations), 1400 ppb(1). Kepone concentrations from samples collected in the Hopewell, VA, area were <20 ppb from the Appomatox River, <20 ppb, and up to 10 ppm from Bailey Creek(1). Another study reported the following results: Dec, 1976-July, 1977, bottom sediments, <0.01-0.15 ppm, channel sediments, not detected (upstream from source in Hopewell, VA) to 0.18 ppm (approx 30 km downstream from source), bed sediments, <0.03 (Chesapeake Bay, near mouth of James River) to >2.0 ppm (near source)(2). Kepone was detected at concentrations of 0.20-0.76 ng/g dry wt in sediment samples collected from three sites around Hong Kong in 2002 and 2003(3); kepone was not detected in sediments collected from three other sites around Hong Kong(3).

Reference: (1) IARC; Some Halogenated Hydrocarbons. IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. 20: 67-81 (1979). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php
(2) Fernandez-Bayo JD et al; Sci Total Environ 463-464: 395-403 (2013)
(3) Davault DA et al; Environ Sci Pollut Int 23: 81-97 (2016)
(4) Martin-Laurent F et al; Environ Sci Pollut Res Int 21: 4928-4933 (2014)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Kepone was detected in soil at a concentration of 0.02 ug/g 12 years after application at 1 ug/g mirex(1). Kepone was found in sediment from a shallow pond at a concentration of 10 ug/g 5 yr after the crash of an aircraft containing mirex(1). Kepone is a degradation product of mirex(1). Kepone was used in banana plantations of the French West Indies to control the weevil, Cosmopolites sordidus(2); despite its prohibition in France in 1993, pollution surveys conducted in 2001 in the French West Indies by the French Department of Health revealed the presence of chlordecone in soils, rivers, springs and drinking water(2). Utilizing a dataset of 810 soil samples collected between 2006 and 2012 in Martinque (French West Indies where kepone had been extensively used in banana plantations in past years), kepone and 5b-hydro-kepone were commonly detected(3); comparison to insecticidal formulations suggested that 5b-hydro-kepone was a natural transformation product of kepone(3). Soil samples from the French West Indies showed kepone concentrations of 0.18 to 35.4 mg/kg in Andosol, Nitisol, Ferralsol, and Fluvisol soil types(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: SOURCE DOMINATED: Kepone concentrations near a Hopewell, VA manufacturing plant sampled in 1975 were as follows with concentration in ng/cu m and (km distance  from plant): May 6, 1.74 (5.21), 1.04 (15.75), 0.17 (20.6), 0.84 (22.72); May 12, not detected, (15.75), 4.94 (22.72), May 18, 4.57 (0.21), 3.63 (5.21), 14.7 (12.57), 20.7 (13.18); May 30, 0.19 (15.75), 1.93 (20.6), 1.41 (22.72) kepone(1). Air samples from a town 16 miles from the Hopewell plant contained kepone levels of 0.1-20 ng/cu m; samples 100 miles from plant, 0.2-50 mg/cu m(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was detected as a contaminant in studies conducted by the FDA from 1978-1982 and 1983-1986 on domestic and imported foods(1,2). A separate study in 1991 found one of the 13,085 food samples to contain detectable amounts of kepone(3). Kepone use in banana plantations in the French West Indies was banned in 1993, but kepone is still being detected in French West Indies foodstuffs (yam, dasheen, sweet potato, cucumber and pumpkin) decades later(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone increased both the quality and quantity of the cotton yield(1). Residues in seeds were always <1 mg/kg, despite different application rates(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was found infrequently, not quantified, in fish by-products sampled in the US in 1976(1). Reported concentrations in 37 fish samples from 8 US rivers, location (number of samples), ppm concentration: 8 sites, 33 samples, 100% positive, Nanticoke, 5 samples, <0.02-0.04 ppm; Potomac, 5 samples, 0.02-<0.05 ppm; Sassafras, 2 samples, <0.02 ppm; Bohemia, 5 samples, <0.02 ppm; Little Elk, 2 samples, <0.02-0.03 ppm; Choptank, 5 samples, <0.02-0.04 ppm; James, 5 samples, <0.07-0.09 ppm; and Rappahannock, 4 samples, 0.03-0.08 ppm(2). Between 1976 and 2002, over 13,000 fish samples from the contaminated James River were monitored for kepone(3); kepone levels in most species began falling when the production of kepone ended (1975), but the average concentrations remained over the action limit of 0.3 ug/g wet weight until the early 1980s(3); by 1988 few fish contained kepone concentrations greater than the action limit(3); as of 2002, kepone was still detected in the majority of white perch and striped bass samples taken from the James River(3). Kepone was detected at concentrations of 0.06 and 0.08 ng/g wet wt in polychaetes and Mylio macrocephalus samples collected from sites around Hong Kong in 2002 and 2003(4); kepone was also detected in various fish species at concentrations of 0.53-3.21 ng/g wet wt(4). Kepone was used in the Lesser Antilles from 1972 to 1993 to fight against a banana weevil(5); from 2003 to 2013, seven campaigns of samplings have been conducted to evaluate the level of kepone contamination of fish, crustaceans, and mollusks with kepone being detected in all three(5); fish usually living at the border of mangrove and presenting detritivores-omnivores diets were the most contaminated by kepone(5).

Reference: (1) Lunsford CA, Blem CR; Estuaries 5: 121-30 (1982)
(2) Reish DJ et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 54: 786-812 (1982)
(3) Reish DJ et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 52: 1533-75 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Monthly average kepone levels (wet weight) in Estuarine clam (Rangia cuneata), taken in the James River Tar Bay area from Sept 1978-Aug 1979, (5 samples each) were: 0.080-0.332 ppm, overall avg 0.21 ppm ; Cobham Bay area, 0.029-0.187 ppm, overall avg 0.10 ppm(1). Monthly average kepone levels (wet weight) in Estuarine clam (Rangia cuneata), taken in the Rappahannock River Tar Bay area from Sept 1978-Aug 1979, (5 samples each) were: 0.002-0.329 ppm, overall avg 0.20 ppm; Cobham Bay area, (0.002-0.219 ppm, overall avg 0.10 ppm(1). Blue crab egg samples from the James River, (Chesapeake Bay) contained kepone at a concentration range of 0.01-0.55 ppm(2). Other reported concentrations in species from the James River estuary were: mullet, 0.560 ppm; (Chesapeake Bay) crab, 0.634-1.36 ppm; croaker, 0.066-0.726 ppm; 0.100-0.534 ppm; and spot, 0.235-0.670 ppm(3).

Reference: (1) Huggett RJ et al; Contam Seds 1: 33-52 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone levels in long- and short-term resident species of the James River, VA were reported (wet weight)(1).[Table#3246]

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in animals.

Reference: (1) Dawson GW; Kepone Mitigation Feasibility Report: Appendix A NTIS Pub No. PB-286,085 as cited in WHO; Environ Health Criteria 43: Chlordecone. World Health Org, Geneve, Switzerland (1984). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://www.inchem.org/pages/ehc.html

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone residues were found in several species of birds that inhabit the Southeastern United States coast, such as the blue heron, mallard duck, coot, black duck, wood duck, herring gull, Canada goose, hooded merganser, and bald eagle(1). Kepone kesidue levels as high as 13.23 mg/kg were reported, but were typically between 0.02 and 2 mg/kg(1). Eggs from bald eagles and the osprey contained residue levels ranging from 0.14 to 0.19 mg/kg, and 0.06 to 1.5 mg/kg, respectively(1).

Reference: (1) Wiemeyer SN et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 24: 213-217 (1993)
(2) Jundreville C et al; Sci Total Environ 493: 336-341 (2014)

StringWithMarkup.String: A study from 1979-1984 found kepone in unhatched eggs of the bald eagle; the presence of the pesticide caused shell thinning with an average of -0.265 mm less than normal for twenty-seven samples(1). Free-range ducks collected in Martinque (French West Indies where kepone had been extensively used in banana plantations until 1993) contained kepone concentrations of 48 to 1051 ug/kg fresh matter indicating continuing contamination decades after the compound was no longer applied(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was detected in the adipose tissue and breast milk of humans that were not occupationally exposed(1), but no quantified amounts were reported. A separate study also found that kepone was detected in breast milk of women and the study predicts the amount transferred to the infant(2). Samples of mother's milk from the southeastern US tested in February, 1976 resulted in 4.5% of 200 samples testing positive for kepone, detected, not quantified(3).

Reference: (1) WHO; Environ Health Criteria 43: Chlordecone. World Health Org, Geneve, Switzerland (1984). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://www.inchem.org/pages/ehc.html

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was found in 9 out of 298 samples of human milk (from the southeastern US) with a relatively high detection limit (1 mg/kg)(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 12,600 workers were potentially exposed to kepone in the USA(1). Occupational exposure to kepone may occur through inhalation  and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where kepone was produced or used(1). However, occupational exposure to kepone should be low or non-existent(SRC) since kepone is no longer produced or used(2). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be, or was formerly exposed to kepone via ingestion of food, in particular fish and dairy products(3). Developing countries used kepone as a pesticide well after the cessation of use in the industrialized world (US, Japan and Western Europe) and the likelihood of exposure through dietary intake in these countries is considerably higher(3). Kepone exposure from drinking water has not been found to constitute significant human exposure since kepone is relatively insoluble in water and rapidly adsorbs to sediment(4). Kepone was used as insecticide in the French West Indies and was intensively applied to banana fields from 1973 to 1993 to control root borers(5); monitoring studies conducted from 1999 to present day (2015) have confirmed that the French West Indian population continues to be exposed to this chemical though consumption of contaminated foodstuffs(5). [

Reference: (1) WHO; Environ Health Criteria 43: Chlordecone. World Health Org, Geneve, Switzerland (1984). Available from, as of Dec 30, 2016: https://www.inchem.org/pages/ehc.html

StringWithMarkup.String: Exposure to kepone may result from dermal absorption or by inhalation. Two sources of kepone exposure for infants are insect traps and human milk. Since tobacco plants were treated with kepone, this may have represented an exposure route, but again no residue data are available to confirm it(1).

Reference: Clayton, G. D. and F. E. Clayton (eds.). Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume 2A, 2B, 2C: Toxicology. 3rd ed. New York: John Wiley Sons, 1981-1982., p. 3737

StringWithMarkup.String: The USA Department of Agriculture (1977) reported 56 incidents of nonoccupational human exposure to kepone. Children under 5 years of age were exposed in 52 of the incidents ... all but nine of the children suffered kepone exposure at home, primarily by devices used for the control of ants and cockroaches ...

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was detected in the adipose tissue of humans that were not occupationally exposed(1), but no quantified amounts were reported. Southeastern USA, Feb, 1976, mothers milk, 200 samples, 4.5% pos, detected, not quantified(2,3). Concentration in blood of workers who manufacture kepone, 32 workers, 0.165-26 ppm(1). Kepone was found in 9 out of 298 samples of human milk with a relatively high detection limit (1 mg/kg)(3).

Reference: Baselt RC; Biological Monitoring Methods for Industrial Chemicals p. 76 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Of 216 blood samples obtained from healthy members of the general population living within a one mile radius of a kepone manufacturing facility, 40 were found to contain detectable amounts of kepone ranging from 0.005-0.033 mg/L. ... Serum concentrations of kepone in 11 occupationally exposed subjects ranged from 0.120 - 2.109 mg/L and average 0.734 mg/L. The average serum half-life was found to be 96 days and the average blood/serum concentration ratio, 0.57.

Reference: Cohn WJ et al; Gastroenterology 71: 901 (1976) as cited in Baselt RC; Biological Monitoring Methods for Industrial Chemicals p.77 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Kepone was found present in blood and biopsy tissues of 32 chemical workers exhibiting symptoms of toxicity; average: 5.8 mg/l (blood), 76 mg/kg (liver), 22 mg/kg (fat).

SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.
